Topic.Title: #$%$ Mexico.

Message.Msg: I've lived among many Mexicans, and South and Central Americans, for several years. Kind, Polite, Gracious, and very friendly folks. And their children are some of the most well behaved that I've ever seen, in any situation. Toddlers included. I'm a Mother, and have 2 who are now 18 and older, who grew up with that same level of security and calmness that I see in the Mexican and South American children that I see on the streets I walk. I was probably much more strict than most of my background, being a White Woman, from a American/Alaska. I grew up in a large family, who didn't have much, until I was out on my own. My children learned a thing or two from me: I raised an eyebrow, and all was quiet on the Fussing Front. And our home had many books for all levels of reading, and plenty of interaction with both parents reading to the children. I'll even publicly thank my exes. I read to our babies from day 2 or 3. What else would a person who doesn't watch TV do? Both of my Ex spouses were quick to hold a baby and reading a story; it beat washing a floor, or a bathroom, or cooking a meal, or... They were comfy in their recliner, the baby was safe and being read to, and it worked for at least 30 mins., most evenings. I didn't mind Sports or the Weather Channel or a biz channel being on the TV, when Dad was on duty. No sitcoms, no movies, no crude language, and no violence, no news (due to violence.) Both of my daughters are probably of a higher IQ than I have. May they both take the opportunity to make the most of their own. I'm not quite certain that I have, of mine...

Topic.Title: Reference to Mexican law.

Message.Msg: Re: Brush up on Mexican law and you will realize this is nothing. Mexican law, okay here is a brush up. No jury Judgment does not hold to precedent as the judge will evaluate each case and judge in the manner he holds germane to the case. Laws are not common but civil. First to file holds court bias. Litigation is not a desirable method of settling disputes. Lititgation can be very expensive. Note Breach of Promise is considered seperate issue from Breach of Contract as it is seperate Breach of Promise is a precontract that is reguired for any base contract. Final judments can take a great deal of time. Only Mexican lawyers may be heard or plea in a Mexican Court. I missed what?

Topic.Title: Reference to Mexican law.

Message.Msg: The verdict probably represents more money than Mexico’s Internet advertising industry has generated thus far, said Brian Wieser, an analyst at Pivotal Research Group LLC in New York. The amount is “incredible in the sense of not being credible as a likely outcome,” Wieser said in an interview.

The verdict probably represents more money than Mexico’s Internet advertising industry has generated thus far, said Brian Wieser, an analyst at Pivotal Research Group LLC in New York. The amount is “incredible in the sense of not being credible as a likely outcome,” Wieser said in an interview.

Message.Title: The amount is “incredible" - Wieser said
Message.Msg: The verdict probably represents more money than Mexico’s Internet advertising industry has generated thus far, said Brian Wieser, an analyst at Pivotal Research Group LLC in New York. The amount is “incredible in the sense of not being credible as a likely outcome,” Wieser said in an interview.

Message.Title: US Steel Corp in mcKeesport PA layoff 142 people
Message.Msg: U.S. Steel Corp. said Friday it’s laying off 142 workers at its McKeesport Tubular Operations plant, which produces pipe for energy-sector and other customers. The Downtown-based steelmaker said high levels of tubular imports made cutbacks necessary, and that it believes many imports are unfairly traded. Ninety-five employees will remain at the McKeesport plant. This is a blow to Obama but Yahoo "news" refuses to share any negative news about this socialist in cheif president.

Message.Title: 2003, Lawsuit & Terry Semel
Message.Msg: So the deal in question was put together in 2003 by Terry Semel and for a while was very successful. By itself this deal got Yahoo Mexico to breakeven. Accordingly, it appears the deal was still going along well after Semel left Yahoo, so now the question becomes which CEO botched the deal. Yang? - I doubt it. He was in over his head, but he wasn't messing around with the company. Bartz? That is where I'd put my money. She's the CEO who famously (Infamously?) insulted Jack ma in front of his staff causing him to loose face and later steal AliPay. I don't doubt she told Yahoo partners to kiss-off - only she most likely did it using her colorful vulgar language. Thompson. No, he wasn't around long enough. MM. Again No, this thing had to be broken before she got to Yahoo. So here is another Bartz mess, in my not so humble opinion.

Topic.Title: Does anyone think Yahoo will have to pay $2.7 billion in Mexican lawsuit?

Message.Msg: After flipping a coin I can say that Yahoo will not pay $2.7 billion. Am I going to make that coin toss rule my trading? No. Just the news that they have this ruling against them is enough. They will appeal and the outcome of that is unknown. This is finding out that a house is in an avalanche zone, there may never be an avalanche that hits the house but just the possibility makes the house drop in value. The possibility of a big loss and proof of management’s failure and incompetence is a kick in the gonads. Yahoo, and Yahoo longs, will take that hit and suffer, recuperate and if they lose the appeal take another hit. First hit is finding out that the house is in an avalanche zone, second hit is the avalanche if it ever falls. Will Yahoo have to pay the $2.7 billion is a question that nobody need answer and won´t be answered for months if not years.

Topic.Title: The Mexican Conspiracy!

Message.Msg: My Mom used to say, as she was beating me with a belt for whatever infraction of my families' or their religious beliefs I might have done: those words. "This is hurting me more than it is hurting you." Really? In whose delusional reality didn't equate getting beaten with a wet leather belt and buckle? I think that would be called "Child Abuse" in today's world. It was accepted as Parental CONtrol, back when I was young. In the 60's, 70's, and probably some of the 80's.

Topic.Title: The Mexican Conspiracy!

Message.Msg: Your mom was mean.

Message.Title: The Fact is that Yahoo has not improved in one single aspect otehr than multimillionaire execs
Message.Msg: This site is worse, the main page is too complex and has nothing that Huffington does not have - in fact a lot less - sports is nothing - finance is out dated - BarChart is much better and provides me with the key information I need in a much more concise way - theses boars have more spam on them and though all email sites can prevent spam Yahoo can not - you can not forward yahoo mail without paying for it so it just sites there unused. The stock is in a bubble - forward PE is higher than Google - AOL is even higher on a % basis. Google news as bad as it is is even more adaptable and has more content. And now the Mexican law suit - whatever is merits or lack thereof it reminds the market that Yahoo has issues that are being hidden. SO who needs Yahoo in a byy out? Microsoft maybe because they are making mistake after mistake. Mayer is the next to get pushed out by the board. At the end of 2013 if Yahoo is not making substantially more than in 2012 she will be fired. The market will hit the stock long before then. Right nowo the analysts say that Yahoo's EPS will NOT go up next year - so how can the stock price continue to trade at a premium when there is no benefit to the company. The accumulation/distributiion shows that there are substantial large block sales going on. The % short will move up percent by percent and then the stock will regress to the mean of 14. Statistically this will happen as certainly as Nate Silver proected the election. Question is, what do you do?

Topic.Title: The Mexican Conspiracy!

Message.Msg: They'll try to extort money out of anyone down there if they think they have half a chance. This will be appealed till hell freezes over and they won't see a dime.

Topic.Title: Is anyone on this board short Yahoo?

Message.Msg: Yes I am happily short at 19.15. Failed resistance. I love shorting stocks at major resistance. Works about 75% of the time and add this one to another one that works. Worst case scenario is if the trade goes bad and the stock pushes through resistance on strong volume you just cover and keep your loss small. No big deal. This is going to be a handsome profit with this major lawsuit! I am salivating at the Monday morning open where I plan on covering and going long. This is going to sell off major but we all this is a #$%$ claim in Mexice but the fact is it will put a major dent in the stock Monday morning. I will monitor the stock after I cover and decide when to go long by looking at the tape. I love this stuff!! Still I see resistance being broken eventually and the stock off to the low to mid 20's in the future.

Message.Title: Someone shorts knew about this judgement beforehand. I saw something brewing
Message.Msg: by studying the tape and noticed the last 2 days some major block sells that had not been ocurring the last few months. Something fishy I thought. So that told me someone knew something and was trading on it. It's all in the tape. While you suckers are yapping away on here I'm watching the tape for clues to make my handsome profits. Watch the tape Monday for clues where YHOO is headed next. If an Ol' southern redneck can become a millionaire trading.....so can you.

Topic.Title: Is anyone on this board short Yahoo?

Message.Msg: Well, dickey_betts44 If you are right and Yahoo eventually rises to the low to mid 20's you just made a mistake. You can post when you cover your $19.15 at $18, $16 or $14 till you are blue in the face. But if the price ever goes above $19.15 the coldone and his minions will still say that you are short $19.15 for as long as Yahoo trades above $19.15. They never sell or post a sale, waiting for their original $28 buying price, and think that nobody ever covers under the short price.
